definition: to do things in a strictly businesslike manner (idiom)

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
matter/thing/item/work/affair/CL:件[jian4],樁|桩[zhuang1],回[hui2]

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
to do/to manage/to handle/to go about/to run/to set up/to deal with

sentences.english: Business is business . You have to pay the bill.
sentences.chinese: 公事公办，妳是要付账的。

sentences.english: She told him in a curt and businesslike manner.
sentences.chinese: 她以一种简洁和公事公办的方式通知他。

sentences.english: Some people prefer to simply get down to business when at the office.
sentences.chinese: 有些人在上班的时候更喜欢公事公办。

sentences.english: Business is business . One can't too particular.
sentences.chinese: 公事公办，谁也不能特殊。

to talk officiously/to assume the air of a functionary/to talk in official jargon
to have a taut face/to pull a long face/to look displeased
a matter of no concern to oneself (idiom)
work-related matters/documents
overbearing/arrogant bully

all smiles/smiling mischievously or ingratiatingly

conducting business impartially (idiom); to act justly

neither haughty nor humble/neither overbearing nor servile/neither supercilious nor obsequious

neither servile nor overbearing (idiom)/neither obsequious nor supercilious
